Recent European environmental directives, the prevalent consumer desire to minimize electricity costs, and the grid-driven need for flexible buildings all lead to a common outcome: the smart sustainable building (SSB). Coordinated by their building energy management systems (BEMS), SSBs steer their operation towards monetary gains for their owners, and flexibility for grid operators. Another key feature is their sustainability, expressed by the mandatory nearly-zero-energy (nZE) mandate, i.e., balancing yearly energy consumption and on-site renewable energy production. In this paper, we present a generic and comprehensive (in terms of device composition) BEMS framework for SSBs. Aside from operating cost minimization, the BEMS is additionally tasked with overseeing the SSB’s environmental profile, ensuring that the nZE mandate is not jeopardized in the pursuit of monetary gains. This is achieved through a novel adaptive sustainability criterion. The inherent uncertainties of solar irradiance and ambient temperature are reflected on the occupants’ thermal comfort, the relevant limitation being cast as chance constraints. The overall mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) problem is solved through model predictive control (MPC). The main contributions lie in the joint consideration of a) a comprehensive devices set, b) weather forecast uncertainties, and c) the employment of the novel adaptive sustainability criterion. The proposed framework is validated in a nigh-exhaustive case study and evaluated with respect to cost management and ability to manage the SSB’s nZE status. the SSB H Set of time instants during the simulation M i Set of energy phases associated with appliance i N Set of appliances i Appliance j Energy phase of appliance k Time instant 1 Introduction The building sector has been widely acknowledged as a major contributor to the global final energy consumption and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions [1]. In an attempt to touch off the improvement of energy performance in the building sector (in light of the 2050 strategy), the European Commission has established legislative frameworks such as the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive 2010/31/EU (EPBD) [2] and the Energy Efficiency Directive 2012/27/EU [3], which dictate that all new buildings be nearly zero-energy (nZE), or sustainable, from 2020 onward. Thanks to these efforts, the sector has progressively been shifting from traditional buildings towards the emergent paradigm of smart sustainable buildings (SSBs) [4]. For SSBs, improving energy efficiency through optimal energy management is only half the story (smart); reducing the overall environmental impact during the operational phase, including greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, is a fundamental, indivisible part of its reasons to be (sustainable). Various measures, mandatory and optional, have been suggested in the EPBD to accomplish these objectives. Most prominently, they include the integration of on-site renewable energy resources, with the prospect that a building’s yearly energy consumption is nearly compensated by its on-site renewable energy production, hence the term nearly zero-energy building (nZEBs) [5,6]. The directive further encourages the use of information/communication technologies, electronic and automated control systems such as building energy management systems (BEMS) to adapt the operation of buildings to the needs of the occupants and, if possible, the grid, and to improve energy efficiency and overall performance [7]. BEMS, with the aid of modern technologies such as smart sensors, smart meters and bi-directional communication with the grid, and demand response schemes, can automatically and optimally steer renewable energy sources (RES), energy storage, and a building’s load to achieve any desired objective [8]. BEMS have been a topic of academic research for several decades, with the focus on energy management through various techniques, ranging from basic rule-based control [9], meta-heuristic evolutionary algorithms [13] to modern approaches like artificial intelligence [14,15], advanced cognitive adaptive optimization approaches [11,10,12], and model predictive control (MPC) [16,17]. In the context of energy management, MPC is well-established as state-of-the-art. The key idea is to solve a new optimization problem at each time step with updated information about the systems’ state and future external disturbances [18]. MPC has been extensively studied as a tool for building energy management under multiple objectives, such as energy cost reduction, energy consumption reduction, thermal comfort improvement, peak-load shaving, or achieving robustness against disturbances [16,19–21]. The majority of these studies mainly focus on the optimal operation heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems (HVACs), which are major drivers in shaping the energy demands of buildings. Under the umbrella of energy management, research has expanded to also investigate the impact of various energy devices, such as photovoltaics (PVs) [22], battery storage systems (BSS), electric vehicles (EVs) [23], and thermal energy storage [24]. Household appliances like dishwashers, washing machines, and clothes dryers are also an important inclusion if one wishes to properly conduct building energy management studies. These smart appliances can provide demand response flexibility in a temporal manner, i.e., their operation can be deferred to more desirable time periods depending on the underlying objective; they are thus commonly referred to as deferrable or shiftable appliances. Many studies opt for using simplistic continuous models [25], or for clustering the load of all shiftable appliances [26], an approach of debatable appropriateness as it pertains to detailed energy management. The proper research avenue is to model their intrinsic operation with sequential operation models, using binary variables [27,28]. A few studies have also investigated the application of MPC for the scheduling of home appliances along with HVAC control [29–31]. However, the vast majority of research works shy away from modelling fully comprehensive sets of the available elements (RES, energy storage, shiftable loads, HVACs, thermal devices). While some researchers have made valiant efforts to (not fully) close this gap in the literature [32,33], relevant research remains sparse. At the moment, the detailed modelling of comprehensive sets of energy devices, within MPC-driven energy management frameworks, remains an underaddressed topic. An additional important challenge to optimal BEMS operation is the inevitable presence of external uncertainties stemming from the forecast of solar irradiance, ambient temperature, and RES. Widely used approaches for combating these uncertainties are scenario-based stochastic programming [34], robust optimization [35,36], and chance-constrained programming [37,38]. These different approaches have their respective advantages and disadvantages. The scenario-based approach makes use of different representative scenarios of different forecast realizations, and is usually computationally expensive. In robust approaches, the optimization problem is solved under the worst-case realization of uncertainty. While easier to implement, the solution to the optimization problem is frequently overly conservative. This work focuses on the chance-constrained programming approach, where constraints that are vulnerable to uncertainties are formulated as probabilistic constraints, which need to be satisfied with a certain probability. Although implementing probabilistic constraints generally leads to intractable problems, if the distribution of uncertain parameters is known beforehand, the optimization problem can be reformulated to its tractable equivalent; this assumption is made in this paper. Another crucial aspect to consider is the building’s environmental impact. Studies have reported that BMES with the sole objective of cost minimization can actually lead to increases in a building’s GHG emissions [39,40]. The environmental aspect of the problem has been tackled by some researchers, by explicitly including the building’s CO 2 footprint cost into the objective function, or by employing multi-objective optimization [40–42]. The consideration of environmental impacts at the design stage of the SSB (when sizing the energy devices) is also very prevalent in some studies [44,45]. In this work, we employ a novel approach to account for the sustainability of the building, initially proposed for the planning stage of the SSB in [46]. Here, the approach is extended to the operation stage of the SSB. It is assumed that the building has sufficient renewable energy capacity to compensate for its yearly energy consumption. Simply put, the building is nZE on paper, i.e., at the design planning stage. However, at the operational phase, the real power generation from RES differs from the expected power generation at the planning stage. When pursuing pure cost optimization, i.e., when environmental considerations “play second fiddle”, the building can often “betray” its fundamental nZE mandate in the name of saving energy costs. To address this, a sustainability criterion is added to the optimization problem, which seeks to maintain the building’s energy consumption below the value expected at the planning stage (no optimization). While minimizing the operational cost remains a driving force of the optimization, the added sustainability criterion effectively upgrades the smart building to a smart sustainable building. This paper presents a comprehensive, generic, energy management framework for SSBs, based on the principles of chance-constrained MPC. The main contributions of the work can be summarised as follows: • It provides an extensive analysis of a comprehensive set of available energy devices (many often disregarded), including the accurate modelling of internal dynamics, for the optimal energy management of SSBs, in an at-least environmentally neutral manner. • It considers the uncertainties in the weather forecasts, with the constraints on the indoor SSB temperature being formulated as probabilistic constraints, which are then rigorously reformulated to equivalent chance constraints. • It proposes, to our knowledge for the first time, an adaptive sustainability criterion that monitors and regulates the SSB’s nZE status, which is in position of being violated when pursuing cost minimization. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the device models and problem formulation. Section 3 formulates the original chance constraints and converts them to tractable equivalents. Section 4 presents the case study and the relevant results. Section 5 concludes and discusses future research directions. 2 Modeling and problem formulation In the proposed framework, the SSB is assumed to host a rich assortment of modern smart appliances: PV, BSS, HVAC system, domestic hot water (DHW) system, time-shiftable appliances (washing machine, dishwasher, clothes dryer) and an EV. It is assumed that the SSB is fully electrified, i.e., its complete load demand, including thermal loads, is supplied by electricity. The system architecture of the proposed framework is presented in Fig. 1 . The BEMS has bi-directional communication with all the energy devices, i.e., it can send activation signals to them and receive information about their current states. The following subsections will present the optimization problem formulation. Let H = { 1 , 2 , … H } be the set of time instants with H as time horizon, and Δ k as the sample time. 2.1 Space heating and cooling demand To determine the thermal demand of the SSB for space heating and cooling, the thermal dynamics of the building need to be modeled. The thermal dynamics of a building are mainly affected by ambient air temperature ( T a ), solar irradiance ( ϕ s ), and heating/cooling power ( ϕ h ) supplied by the HVAC system. The overall thermal dynamics of the building are modeled using a lumped-capacitance method with indoor air temperature ( T i ) and the temperature of the internal heat-accumulating medium ( T m ) as states. Internal mass such as furniture, floor, and ceiling, etc., are lumped into the internal heat-accumulating medium. The thermal dynamics of the building are represented by the following first-order differential equations: (1) C m T ̇ m = ( T i - T m ) R im + A w . p . ϕ s C i T ̇ i = ( T m - T i ) R im + ( T a - T i ) R ia + η h ϕ h + A w . ( 1 - p ) . ϕ s The continuous differential equations in Eq. (1) are discretized into difference equations using Δ k as sample time. In the real-world practices, the optimal temperature set-points are used as the control inputs to the HVAC system. To model this behavior, a relationship between the temperature set-points and power consumption of the HVAC system can be established using system identification techniques [43]. For the sake of simplicity and to emphasize the overall energy management framework, the authors assumed that the heating and cooling of the HVAC system can be controlled directly. The heating and cooling demand of the building is determined based on Eqs. (1) and (2) which ensure that the temperature of indoor air must be maintained between a specified temperature range of T i min and T i max (thermal comfort). (2) T i min , k - v 1 , k ⩽ T i , k ⩽ T i max , k + v 2 , k ∀ k ∈ H v 1 , k , v 2 , k ⩾ 0 ∀ k ∈ H where v 1 and v 2 represent non-negative slack variables. These slack variables are introduced to avoid numerical infeasibility issues of the optimization problem in case the constraints can not be satisfied. There is usually a large penalty associated with these variables, which is included in the objective function of the optimization problem. This is to ensure that constraints are not compromised unnecessarily. These types of constraints are referred to as soft constraints. In addition to constraints on indoor temperature, maximum and minimum allowed power consumption of HVAC system at any given time instant k is also restricted between ϕ h min and ϕ h max . (3) ϕ h min ⩽ ϕ h , k ⩽ ϕ h max ∀ k ∈ H 2.2 DHW demand Domestic hot water is considered to be supplied by a hot water storage tank (HWST). The temperature ( T tnk ) of the HWST is affected by heat loss to the ambient, power supplied by the heating element ( ϕ h tnk ), and power consumption ϕ c occurred during hot water consumption. The overall model is given in Eq. (4) which governs the energy balance in the tank. Eq. (7) can be rewritten in terms of state-of-charge (SOC) of the battery using the following relation: (8) S k = E BSS , k E BSS , max ∀ k ∈ H where S k denotes the SOC of BSS at time instant k. E BSS , max is the maximum energy storage capacity of the BSS. For efficient operation of the BSS, the SOC is considered to be maintained between a specified range S min and S max as given in the following equation (9) S min ⩽ S k ⩽ S max ∀ k ∈ H The charging and discharging of a battery is considered to be restricted by the maximum charging ( P c , max ) and discharging power P d , max . Further constraint need to be enforced to prevent simultaneous charging and discharging of the BSS. These two conditions are put together in the following equations (10a) 0 ⩽ P c , k ⩽ P c , max ζ 1 k ∀ k ∈ H (10b) 0 ⩽ P d , k ⩽ P d , max ζ 2 k ∀ k ∈ H (10c) ζ 1 k + ζ 2 k ⩽ 1 ∀ k ∈ H where ζ 1 and ζ 2 are binary variables representing the charging and discharging status of the BSS, i.e., if ζ 1 is 1 then the BSS is charging and if ζ 2 is 1 then the BSS is discharging. Eq. (10c) ensures that the BSS does not charge and discharge simultaneously. Eq. (10a) and (10b) force the charging and discharging power to not exceed the maximum charging and discharging power. Notice that when ζ 1 or ζ 2 are 0, Eqs. (10a) and (10b) collapses to keep the charging and discharging power at zero. 2.4 Shiftable appliances Shiftable appliances provide further demand-response flexibility to the SSB by deferring their power consumption to more desirable time periods depending upon BEMS objective. For example, with minimization of energy cost, shiftable appliances operation can be shifted to low-electricity prices period. Shiftable appliances considered in this work include a washing machine, clothes dryer, and dishwasher. The operation of shiftable appliances can be modeled using different methods. We adopt the approach of sequential operation of appliances considering different energy phases within each appliance [47]. The shiftable appliances usually operate in different energy phases; for instance, the first phase of a dishwasher is pre-washing the dishes and then move on to wash, rinse, and drain phases, etc. The power consumption of the appliance is different during different energy phases but is considered to remain constant during each phases’s operation. So, the overall operation of an appliance is divided into the operation of its energy phases. 2.4.1 Decision variables In order to model the intricate operation of shiftable appliances, some decision variables need to be declared first. Let N = { 1 , 2 , … N } denote the set of appliances and M i = { 1 , 2 , … M i } denote the set of energy phases associated with appliance i ∈ N . The first decision variable is a binary variable α i , j k which represents the ON/OFF status of appliance i ∈ N in energy phase j at time step k ∈ H , i.e., a value of 1 corresponds to the ON status and 0 to the OFF status of the appliance. The power consumption of the appliance i during energy phase j at time instant k is denoted by P i , j k . An auxiliary binary variable β i , j k is defined which is used to indicate the finishing status of an energy phase j of appliance i at time instant k. If an energy phase j of appliance i has finished its operation at time instant k , β i , j k assumes the value of 1 and remains unchanged after. In addition, another auxiliary binary variable γ i , j k is defined which assists in keeping track of waiting time between the operation of two energy phases of an appliance or between two different appliances. 2.4.2 Operational time constraint Each energy phase j of an appliance i needs to be run for a specific time duration Ω i , j to finish the task assigned to it. This condition can be fulfilled by applying the following constraint (11) ∑ k ∈ H α i , j k = Ω i , j ∀ i ∈ N , ∀ j ∈ M i (12) α i , j k = 0 ∀ k ∈ F i , j where F i , j denotes the set of time instants when the energy phase j of appliance i is not allowed to operate. 2.4.3 Continuous operation constraint It is assumed that once an energy phase j of appliance i has started at time instant k, it remains uninterrupted and operates continuously until the energy phase has finished its task. This constraint can be defined using the auxiliary variable β i , j k as follows (13a) α i , j k + β i , j k ⩽ 1 ∀ i ∈ N , j ∈ M i , k ∈ H (13b) α i , j k - 1 - α i , j k ⩽ β i , j k ∀ i ∈ N , j ∈ M i , k = 2 , 3 … H (13c) β i , j k - 1 ⩽ β i , j k , ∀ i ∈ N , j ∈ M i , k = 2 , 3 … H In the above set of constraints, constraint (13a) describes that when energy phase j of appliance i is in operation at time instant k , α i , j k is 1 and consequently β i , j k is 0 indicating that the energy phase is not finished yet. As the energy phase is over, Eq. (13b) forces β i , j k to switch from 0 to 1 suggesting that energy phase has finished. Eq. (13c) ensures that once the energy phase is finished β i , j k remains 1 for the rest of the time horizon. 2.4.4 Sequential operation constraint The operation of energy phases of an appliance needs to be in a particular order and the next energy phase can start only when the previous energy phase is over. Further, such dependence can exist between different appliances also. For example - the clothes dryer should be activated only after the washing machine has finished its operation. This condition can be enforced as follows (14) α i , j k ⩽ β i , j - 1 k ∀ i ∈ N , k ∈ H , j = 2 , 3 , … M i Eq. (14) ensures that energy phase j is only activated once energy phase j - 1 is finished. 2.4.5 Delay constraint In order to provide additional time flexibility, it is assumed that the operation of the next energy phase can be delayed up to a certain time limit after finishing the previous energy phase. This constraint is enforced with assistance from another auxiliary variable γ i , j k , which is defined as follows (15) γ i , j k = β i , j - 1 k - ( α i , j k + β i , j k ) ∀ i ∈ N , k ∈ H , j = 2 , 3 , … M i As per Eq. (15), γ i , j k assumes value of 1 only when energy phase j - 1 of appliance i has finished at time slot k and energy phase j is yet to start. Once energy phase j is started at time step k , γ i , j k switches its value back to 0. So the delay constraint can be formulated as follows (16) D i , j min ⩽ ∑ k ∈ H γ i , j k ⩽ D i , j max ∀ i ∈ N j = 2 , 3 , … M i where D i , j min and D i , j max denote the minimum and maximum time delay allowed between the energy phase j and j - 1 for appliance i. It should be noted that the sequential operation constraint and delay constraint defined in Eqs. (14)–(16) can be modified to model sequential operation of different appliances and delay between them. 2.5 EV battery model In addition to meeting the customer’s driving requirements, EV can also provide additional flexibility to the SSB in the demand response framework. Like the BSS, the EV battery can also be charged/discharged in an optimal manner and modeled using the energy balance approach. For the EV battery, the state-of-charge ( S EV , k ) at any time instant k is dependent upon charging power ( P EV , c k ), discharging power ( P EV , d k ) and power demand of EV for driving ( π k ). (17) S EV , k + 1 = S EV , k + Δ k E EV , max η EV , c P EV , c k - P EV , d k η EV , d - π k EV battery is required to have a certain SOC value of θ when the vehicle leaves the SSB at time step l. This is ensured by imposing the following constraint: (18) S EV , l ⩾ θ For efficient operation of the EV battery, SOC is restricted to be maintained between the minimum ( S EV , min ) and maximum ( S EV , max ) SOC values as written in Eq. (19). (19) S EV , min ⩽ S k ⩽ S EV , max ∀ k ∈ H The charging and discharging power of EV battery need to be lower than their respective maximum values of P EV , c max and P EV , d max . Similar to the BSS, the charging and discharging of the EV battery can not happen simultaneously. Further, it is assumed that the EV battery is not plugged in for charging/discharging at any other places than the SSB i.e. the battery will charge/discharge only while the vehicle is parked at the SSB. The following constraints formulate these conditions as: (20a) 0 ⩽ P EV , c k ⩽ P EV , c max μ 1 k ∀ k ∈ H (20b) 0 ⩽ P EV , d k ⩽ P EV , d max μ 2 k ∀ k ∈ H (20c) μ 1 k + μ 2 k ⩽ 1 ∀ k ∈ H (20d) μ 1 k , μ 2 k = 0 ∀ k ∈ G ⊂ H where μ 1 and μ 2 are binary variables representing the status of charging and discharging of EV battery. G denotes the set of time instants when the vehicle is not parked at the SSB. 2.6 Power exchange with the grid A bi-directional power exchange with the power grid is considered, i.e., in addition to purchasing power from the grid, it is possible to sell excess power back to the grid. It is assumed that power selling ( P sell ) and purchasing ( P pur ) to/from the grid can not happen simultaneously. This is ensured by defining two binary variables ψ 1 and ψ 2 and adding the following constraint: (21a) 0 ⩽ P pur , k ⩽ P pur , max ψ 1 k ∀ k ∈ H (21b) 0 ⩽ P sell , k ⩽ P sell , max ψ 2 k ∀ k ∈ H (21c) ψ 1 k + ψ 2 k ⩽ 1 ∀ k ∈ H where P pur , max and P sell , max are the maximum power values that can be purchased from and sold to the grid respectively. 2.7 PV power generation The power generated by the photovoltaic panel depends upon the amount of solar radiation. In this work, the PV power profile is obtained from the PV performance tool, which is a part of the photovoltaic geographical information system (PVGIS) available from the European Commission [48]. 2.8 Power balance constraint This constraint is to ensure power balance in the building, i.e., at any time instant k, the total power generation is equal to the total power consumption. (22) P sell , k + P c , k + P EV , c k + | ϕ h , k | + ∑ i ∈ N ∑ j ∈ M i P i , j k α i , j k + ϕ h tnk , k = P PV k + P pur , k + P d , k + P EV , d k ∀ k ∈ H 2.9 Sustainability criterion As previously mentioned, the BEMS aims to not only optimize the operational energy cost, but to also achieve the desired sustainability target, i.e., the nZE mandate. At the design stage, it is assumed that the building has the capability to produce as much energy as it consumes by PV power generation on an yearly basis (nZEB). The real PV power generation at the operational stage is usually different from the expected PV power generation at the planning stage. Because the objective of a conventional BEMS is to simply minimize the operational cost, and since there is no restriction on the exchange with the power grid, it is entirely possible that the SSB’s energy consumption actually exceeds the envisioned levels of consumption. In that light, and in wishing to maintain the SSB’s sustainability, the following sustainability criterion is imposed in the following manner: (23) P pur , k - P sell , k Δ k + ∑ j = 1 k - 1 P pur , j - P sell , j Δ k - ∑ j = 1 k - 1 E j ︸ underconsumption / overconsumption ⩽ E k + v 5 where v 5 is a non-negative slack variable and E k is the expected energy consumption at the time step k derived from the planning stage. • At the first time step, the following constraint is imposed which ensure that the net energy consumption is less than or equal to zero (24) P pur , k - P sell , k Δ k ⩽ E 1 + v 5 E 1 is the expected energy consumption, obtained at the planning stage. • At the next time step, if the net energy consumption was more than the expected value, i.e. v 5 > 0 in the previous time step, and the building overconsumed E 1 ∗ energy; then the following constraint will be enforced at the next time step (25) P pur , k - P sell , k Δ k + E 1 ∗ ⩽ E 2 + v 5 In other words, the constraint is tightened based upon the energy consumption at the previous time step. • But if the net energy consumption was less than or equal to the expected value at the previous time step, i.e. v 5 = 0 , and the building underconsumed E 1 ∗ energy; then the following constraint will be put into action (26) P pur , k - P sell , k Δ k - E 1 ∗ ⩽ E 2 + v 5 In other words, the constraint is relaxed based upon the energy consumption at the previous time step. 2.10 Overall problem formulation In this work, it is considered that the objective J of the optimization problem is to minimize the energy consumption cost of the building for entire time horizon. (27) J = ∑ k ∈ H C k ( P pur , k - P sell , k ) + ∑ n = 1 4 ρ n v n , k + ρ 5 v 5 where C k is the electricity price at time instant k. It is assumed that electricity prices are known with complete certainty. ρ is a large number, used to penalize the objective function so that violation of constraints in Eq. (2) and (5) occurs only if these constraints can not be met. The overall optimization is formulated as follows (28) min { ϕ h , k , ϕ h tnk , k , α i , j k , P pur , k , P sell , k , P c , k , P d , k , P EV , c k , P EV , d k } J subject to equations ( 1 ) – ( 23 ) The resulting optimization problem is a mixed-integer-linear-programming (MILP) problem which is solved in a model predictive control framework, i.e., at each time step, the optimization problem is solved over the time horizon H and an optimal control policy ( Q ∗ = { q 1 ∗ , q 2 ∗ … q H ∗ } ) is computed. Only the first control variable vector ( { q 1 ∗ } ) is applied to the model and other control vectors are discarded. At the next time step, the process is repeated in a rolling horizon manner with the updated values of the state of the model and disturbance forecasts. It should be noted that the optimization problem in Eq. (28) is of deterministic nature, i.e., we assume perfect solar irradiance and external temperature forecast. 3 Chance-constrained formulation 3.1 Uncertainty model The intrinsic uncertainties in the forecast of external disturbances due to solar irradiance and ambient air temperature can affect the indoor air temperature, which can further lead to jeopardizing the thermal comfort. To avoid this, the BEMS needs to account for these uncertainties when making the optimal decisions. The solar irradiance and the external temperature forecasts can be modeled as follows (29) ϕ s = ϕ ̃ s + ϕ ̂ s T a = T ̃ a + T ̂ a where the diacritic ∼ over the variables represents the forecast value and ̂ represents the uncertainty associated with the forecast of corresponding variable. The uncertainties in both the solar irradiance and ambient temperature are assumed to be random variables which follow the normal distribution: T ̂ a k ∼ N μ T a k , ( σ T a k ) 2 and ϕ ̂ s k ∼ N μ ϕ k s , ( σ ϕ k s ) 2 with μ T a k , μ ϕ k s as the means and ( σ T a k ) 2 , ( σ ϕ k s ) 2 as the variances of the uncertainty distributions. Since the model of thermal dynamics of the building are assumed linear, the indoor temperature will also be a random variable that will follow a normal distribution: T i ∼ N ( μ T i , σ T i 2 ) . 3.2 State-space formulation The thermal model of the building in Eq. (1) including the uncertainties from Eq. (29) is written in a state-space form for convenience as follows: (30) x k + 1 = A x k + Bu k + E ( d k + w k ) (31) y k + 1 = C x k + 1 ∀ k ∈ H where x = [ T m , T i ] T represents the state of the system, u = ϕ h is the control input, d = [ T ̃ a , ϕ ̃ s ] T is the disturbances to the system, w = [ T ̂ a , ϕ ̂ s ] T is the uncertainty in the disturbance forecast, y = T i is the output of the system. A , B , C and E are the system matrices. Let’s define the following stacked vectors for systems’ states, inputs, disturbances, uncertainties and outputs over the prediction horizon H (32) X = x 2 T x 3 T … x H T x H + 1 T T (33) U = u 1 u 2 … u H - 1 u H T (34) D = d 1 T d 2 T … d H - 1 T d H T T (35) W = w 1 T w 2 T … w H - 1 T w H T T (36) Y = y 2 T y 3 T … y H T y H + 1 T T The complete prediction model over the prediction horizon H can be with prediction dynamics matrices A , B , C and E can be written as (37) X = Ax 1 + B U + E ( D + W ) (38) Y = C X 3.3 Analytical reformulation Next, the thermal comfort constraints in Eq. (2) are reformulated as chance constraints, i.e., the constraint should be satisfied with a certain user-specified probability. For this, the constraints on the maximum and minimum limit of indoor temperature are separated and rewritten as following probabilistic constraints or chance constraints (39a) P ( T i , k ⩾ T i min , k ) ⩾ 1 - ∊ 1 k ∀ k ∈ H (39b) P ( T i , k ⩽ T i max , k ) ⩾ 1 - ∊ 2 k ∀ k ∈ H where P represents the probability function. ∊ 1 , ∊ 2 ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) are the allowed constraint violation level and consequently 1 - ∊ 1 , 1 - ∊ 2 are the probabilistic confidence level i.e., at each time step the thermal comfort constraints should be satisfied with a probability of 1 - ∊ 1 / 1 - ∊ 2 at each time step of the prediction horizon. Statistically, if simulation is run large number of times, the constraints will be satisfied ( ( 1 - ∊ 1 / 1 - ∊ 2 ) × 100 % ) times. The probabilistic constraints in Eq. (39) are not tractable due to the random nature of the uncertainties. These constraints can be reformulated analytically into equivalent deterministic constraints as follows [49] (40a) T i , k ⩾ T i min , k - ∑ j = 0 k - 1 CA j E μ w k - j + Φ - 1 ( 1 - ∊ 1 k ) ∑ j = 0 k - 1 ∥ Ξ w k - j 1 / 2 ( CA j E ) ∥ 2 (40b) T i , k ⩽ T i max , k - ∑ j = 0 k - 1 CA j E μ w k - j - Φ - 1 ( 1 - ∊ 2 k ) ∑ j = 0 k - 1 ∥ Ξ w k - j 1 / 2 ( CA j E ) ∥ 2 where Φ - 1 (.) represents the inverse of cumulative distribution function of standard normal distribution, also called quantile function. μ w and Ξ w represent the mean and covariance matrix of the uncertainty vector w . Notice that, Eqs. (40a) and (40b) are the tightened versions of thermal comfort constraints in Eq. (2). Obviously, slack variables can also be added to the Eqs. (40a) and (40b) to avoid the numerical infeasibility of the optimization problem. Fig. 2 compares the original constraints and analytically reformulated chance constraints used in optimization problem at the initial time instant. We can see that the chance constraints are tighter than the original constraints. Further, the tightness of constraints increases with time because as it is clear from the Eq. (40) that the effect of uncertainty on indoor temperature adds up with time which results in increased tightening of the constraints. So, the optimization problem with consideration of uncertainties in the forecast of solar irradiance and external temperature takes the form of a stochastic MILP (41) min { ϕ h , k , ϕ h tnk , k , α i , j k , Pg pur , k , Pg sell , k , P ch , k , P dch , k } E [ J ] ∀ i , j (42) subject to equations ( 1 ) – ( 27 ) , ( 29 ) – ( 40 ) where E [ J ] denotes the expected value of the cost function J . Fig. 3 describes the overall energy management framework with a flowchart representation. 4 Numerical case study 4.1 Simulation setup To demonstrate the advantage of the proposed framework, a simulation case study is carried out. The parameters values for the building are adopted from [50] and are presented in Table A.4. The proposed framework applies to any general building. Since the modeling of the HVAC system is out of the scope of the present work, it is assumed that space heating and hot water demand are satisfied using a heat pump with a constant coefficient of performance (COP) of 3. For the HWST, a tank of effective volume 0.2  m 3 is considered with overall heat loss coefficient ( U tnk A tnk ) of 1.63  W / K [51]. The power consumption that occurs during hot water consumption is derived from typical domestic hot water usage profiles [52]. The weather data is obtained from the typical meteorological year (TMY) generator tool of PVGIS [53]. For energy storage, a Lithium-ion BSS with 3.6 kWh energy storage capacity with a rated power of 2 kW is utilized [54]. An EV with a battery capacity of 16 kWh and rated power of 3.6 kW is considered [55]. For shiftable appliances, the parameters used in the study are adopted from [47] and are presented in Table A.5, where i = 1 , 2 and 3 refers to the washing machine, clothes dryer, and dishwasher respectively. The shiftable appliances have an operation frequency of once per day and are allowed to operate between a predefined beginning time and end time. A maximum delay of 15 min (1 time step) is considered between consecutive energy phases and the clothes dryer is allowed to delay its operation for 30 min after the washing machine finishes its operation. The time instants during which the appliances are allowed to run are based on general assumptions, such as the user preferring to not run shiftable appliances during nighttime. For electricity cost, historical market data for wholesale energy price provided by Nord Pool is employed [56] and have been scaled up to represent the retail electricity prices. The optimization problem is formulated in Matlab with YALMIP interface [57] and is solved using CPLEX optimizer [58] with default optimality gap of 10−4. The simulation is performed with a sample time of Δ k  = 15 min and a prediction horizon of H = 24 hours. 4.2 Numerical results 4.2.1 Deterministic MPC The building-grid power exchange for the examined 24-h period is shown in Fig. 4 , where 4(a), (b) show the power drawn from and injected into the grid, respectively. As is evident, the BEMS takes full advantage of the varying electricity prices, concentrating the building’s power import peaks to the periods with lowest local energy prices. Contrariwise, periods with low local energy prices see substantial activity from the BSS, EV and PV, which together inject large energy amounts into the grid (providing significant flexibility to the grid operator). The building is efficiently operating, with its overall operating cost being minimized. The maximum power import from the grid occurs towards the end of the day when all the shiftable loads are activated. It is interesting to examine how the BEMS designs the cost minimization strategy, while at the same time monitoring the occupants’ thermal comfort. The balance maintenance between the these two aspects of the problem can be visualized with the help of Fig. 5 , which presents the behavior of the HVAC system and of the thermal comfort profile with respect to the temperature constraints (Fig. 5(a), (b), respectively). The black dotted line represents the time varying constraints on indoor temperature of the building. At time step 17, the heat pump starts preheating the building until the time step 28 since the energy prices are low during this period. This heat is released to the indoor air during time step 29 to 57, avoiding the need for heating during this period since the energy cost is higher. Similarly, at time step 57, the heat pump preheats the building which is released to the indoor air at a later time. Towards the end of the day, when electricity prices drop significantly, the heat pump runs at full power and preheat the building again. The thermal comfort of the occupant is always maintained during the simulation period. Fig. 6 demonstrates how the BEMS can make use of the activation delay capability of shiftable appliances. Fig. 6 shows the intrinsic operation of different energy phases of the washing machine. After the first energy phase has completed it cycle time, rather than go to the second phase immediately, a short time buffer is applied until its “activation”. This decision is not random; it is rather a strategic choice by the BEMS, which delays the second phase for onetime step so that energy prices can slightly drop, allowing for more cost-saving. This observation is echoed in the virtually identical behavior demonstrated by the dishwasher also. To demonstrate the cost-saving achieved by using the proposed scheme, the building is simulated with a baseline scenario for a period of 10 days, under both winter and summer conditions, and the results are compared with the proposed approach. For the baseline case, the BEMS is not concerned with the building’s cost; instead, its sole concern is to maintain the temperature of indoor air and water in the HWST between the assigned values (i.e., adhere to the thermal comfort limits). The shiftable loads are neither deferred nor delayed, and are activated as soon as the relevant request is received. Table 1 shows the power exchange and electricity cost for the baseline scenario and the proposed approach. The proposed approach achieves almost a 34% reduction in energy cost for the simulation period in winter compared to the baseline case. In summer, the BEMS is able to attain almost twice the cost-saving in comparison with the baseline scenario. A significant reduction in energy usage can also be seen for deterministic MPC as compared to the baseline case; this is directly associated with the energy consumption in the heat pump. Due to the absence of any optimization-driven decision for the baseline case, the heat pump system is made to constantly restore rather than maintain the occupants’ thermal comfort. Naturally, behaving in a reactive manner rather than a predictive one, leads to unnecessarily high energy consumption. 4.2.2 Deterministic MPC with sustainability criterion To ensure the nZE mandate of the SSB, a sustainability criterion was imposed in Eq. (23). As was made clear, if the actual PV generation is below the forecasted value, a BEMS with the sustainability criterion will attempt to keep the energy consumption below the expected energy consumption (originally determined from the no-optimization baseline case), attempting to remain as close as possible to the SSB’s starting nZE target. Fig. 7 (a), (b) shows the cumulative net power consumption comparison between the proposed approach (sustainability criterion enforced) and the baseline approach for a 10 days period during the month of January and June, respectively. As is evident the sustainable BEMS consistently keeps the building’s net power consumption below the expected net power consumption. Obviously, the net power consumption is expected to steadily increase during winter months, and demonstrate the exact opposite behavior during summer months. This is evidently the case, as is shown in Fig. 7(a), (b). Downward spikes represent time instants when the power generation is higher than power consumption and vice versa. An observation of great value lies on the development of the building’s energy profile: that for both the months simulated, the BEMS actually “saves” approximately 125 kWh of net energy. This leads to coin-flip, win–win situation: if the remainder of the forecast is reasonably accurate, the BEMS achieves cost minimization with an even lower net consumption that originally envisioned. On the other hand, if the PV production does not meet the forecast, the BEMS has effectively built an internal “net energy reserve” which can be accessed throughout the year to mitigate forecast imbalances. This way, the SSB both arms itself against periods of unpredictably low production, and leaves itself more leeway for cost minimization. Table 2 shows the comparison of energy cost and consumption for deterministic MPC with and without the sustainability criterion over a 1-day simulation period with PV power availability ranging from 0% to 100%. The sustainability-driven energy consumption is consistently lower because BEMS tries to operate the appliances with minimal energy usage in order to maintain the nZE status of the SSB. Even with the lower energy consumption, the energy cost increases slightly. This is because of the emphasis given to sustainability, which makes the BEMS use minimal energy at the expense of increased cost. It should be noted that there may also exist such situations when the energy cost is the same for both cases. 4.2.3 Chance-constrained MPC Unlike deterministic MPC, in this case, the solar irradiance and external temperature forecast is assumed to be uncertain as shown in Eq. (29). As was the intended target, the magnitude of thermal comfort constraints violations decreases with chance-constrained MPC (see Table 3 ). However, the energy cost increases in this case; this is due to the tightening of constraints, hence less provision for demand-response flexibility. The heat pump compressor consumes more power to maintain the indoor temperature between the tightened constraints leading to higher energy cost. As per Eq. (40), the constraint becomes even more tightened as the value of ∊ decreases or the constraint satisfaction probability increases. However, this leads to increased cost as shown in Fig. 8 . It is essential to validate the chance constraint formulation proposed in Eq. (40) and see if the constraint is satisfied with 1 - ∊ probability. In order to do that, 1000 Monte Carlo simulations were performed with σ T a = 1.5 , σ ϕ s = 0.1 , and ∊ 1 = ∊ 2 = 0.9 at the initial time instant. Fig. 9 shows the frequency of violation of constraints at each time step of prediction horizon with chance-constrained MPC. The dotted line represents the frequency corresponding to the allowed limit on constraint violation probability of 0.1. The constraint violation frequency is either 0 or negligible outside the occupancy hours since the thermal comfort range is more relaxed during this period. During the occupancy hours, the constraint violation frequency is below the allowed violation limit for the vast majority of time. Regarding the computation efforts, the optimization problem contains 1920 continuous variables and 2592 integer variables at each time. The optimization solvers takes around 0.145 s to find a feasible optimal solution at each iteration when run for ten days simulation period (see Fig. 10 ), which indicates a high scalability of the proposed approach. Generally, the chance-constrained optimization approaches have higher computation complexity due to the intractable nature of probabilistic constraints. However, in the present case, the equivalent reformulated constraint in Eq. (40) are convex and deterministic due to the model and constraints linearity and assumption of Gaussian distribution for the uncertainty. Therefore, the computational time for chance-constraint MPC is of similar magnitude to the computation time of deterministic MPC. 4.3 Discussion The major takeaways of this work can be summarized as follows: • BEMS plays an important role in the operation of energy devices of an SSB. It can optimally steer a large variety of energy resources (e.g. HVAC, DHW system, shiftable loads, PV, BSS and EV battery) in the SSB to achieve minimum energy cost for the occupant while maintaining the occupant’s comfort. • Intrinsic uncertainties in solar irradiance and ambient temperature can jeopardize the thermal comfort of the occupants. The use of a chance-constrained approach successfully maintains the thermal comfort with a very high probability defined by the occupant. • Minimizing the cost does not necessarily guarantee the minimum environmental impacts for an SSB. Further, the nZE status of the building can be compromised due to the mismatch between the real RES generation at the operation stage and forecast RES generation at the design stage. Therefore, by adding a sustainability criterion, BEMS attempts to maintain the nZE status of the SSB along with cost minimization. 5 Concluding remarks and future work This paper has presented a generic framework for a BEMS by modeling smart energy devices in an SSB. The mathematical models for energy devices presented in the work apply to a wide variety of buildings with different conditions such as size or user preferences. The proposed BEMS framework achieved almost a 34% reduction in energy cost in winter and almost double the energy saving in summer in comparison to the baseline approach for the considered simulation period. With chance-constrained MPC, the thermal comfort violation is reduced at the expense of increased energy cost, so there is a trade-off between occupant comfort and cost reduction. With the sustainability criterion, BEMS maintained the power consumption below the expected power consumption from the baseline approach; however, this was also achieved at the expense of increased electricity cost. Although the proposed approach is generic and scalable, the work is based upon the assumption of an existing smart grid infrastructure where the grid can communicate with the SSB in real-time. Another point to note is that obtaining the dynamical model for the thermal behavior of the building is not straightforward, it requires extensive data gathering. However, it has become possible lately, thanks to the advancements in sensor and metering technologies and internet-of-things. The future work will include the implementation and testing of the proposed framework in a lab setting with presented energy devices. On a conceptual level, the current approach will be extended to a cluster of SSBs with an idea of applying distributed MPC in a cooperative optimization structure. coredata.dc:description: Recent European environmental directives, the prevalent consumer desire to minimize electricity costs, and the grid-driven need for flexible buildings all lead to a common outcome: the smart sustainable building (SSB). Coordinated by their building energy management systems (BEMS), SSBs steer their operation towards monetary gains for their owners, and flexibility for grid operators. Another key feature is their sustainability, expressed by the mandatory nearly-zero-energy (nZE) mandate, i.e., balancing yearly energy consumption and on-site renewable energy production. In this paper, we present a generic and comprehensive (in terms of device composition) BEMS framework for SSBs. Aside from operating cost minimization, the BEMS is additionally tasked with overseeing the SSB’s environmental profile, ensuring that the nZE mandate is not jeopardized in the pursuit of monetary gains. This is achieved through a novel adaptive sustainability criterion. The inherent uncertainties of solar irradiance and ambient temperature are reflected on the occupants’ thermal comfort, the relevant limitation being cast as chance constraints. The overall mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) problem is solved through model predictive control (MPC). The main contributions lie in the joint consideration of a) a comprehensive devices set, b) weather forecast uncertainties, and c) the employment of the novel adaptive sustainability criterion. The proposed framework is validated in a nigh-exhaustive case study and evaluated with respect to cost management and ability to manage the SSB’s nZE status.
coredata.dc:title: Optimal energy management in smart sustainable buildings – A chance-constrained model predictive control approach
